sections.heading: EFFECT OF SiC NANO-PARTICLES ON MICROSTRUCTURE AND MECHANICAL PROPERTIES OF THE CoCrFeMnNi HIGH ENTROPY ALLOY
sections.text:
Łukasz Rogal1a, Damian Kalita1, Anna Tarasek1, Piotr Bobrowski1, Frank Czerwinski 2
1)Institute of Metallurgy and Materials Science, Polish Academy of Sciences, Reymonta 25 St., 30-059 Krakow, Poland 2)CanmetMATERIALS, Natural Resources Canada, 183 Longwood Road South, Hamilton, ON Canada L8P 0A5
Corresponding author: a) Ł. Rogal, l.rogal@imim.pl,tel.+48 122952801, fax +48 122952804

sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text:
Novel metal matrix nanocomposites were designed exploring the CoCrFeMnNi high entropy alloy as a matrix and SiC spherical nanoparticles with a diameter of 20-50 nm as a reinforcement phase, and manufactured by mechanical alloying followed by hot isostatic sintering. After reaction at 1000˚C for 15 min the microstructure consisted of a matrix with a face centered solid solution of all elemental ingredients with traces of M23C6/M7C3 carbides (where M= Cr, Fe, Co), σ-phase and SiC nano-particles distributed along grain boundaries of the matrix. Additions of 5 wt.% of SiC nano-particles increased the room temperature compressive yield strength of the CoCrFeMnNi base from 1180 MPa to 1480 MPa, accompanied by a decrease in compressive strength and plasticity. The results are discussed in terms of mechanisms controlling the strengthening process in nano-composites with high entropy alloy matrix.
Key words: high entropy alloys, nano-composites, SiC particles, TEM
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
2
1. Introduction High Entropy Alloys (HEAs) represent a new class of materials with superior properties being stable over wide temperature ranges that often constitute an alternative to traditional alloys such as steel or compositions based on aluminium, magnesium and titanium. The early HEAs explored mainly single crystallographic lattices and there are examples of sets of four or more elements within groups from III to XII of the periodic table, which crystallize as simple solid solutions of BCC [1] or FCC [2]. Recent research led to the development of new HEAs such as hexagonal close-packed (HCP) [3], eutectic mixtures [4-6] or alloys with disordered structures of solid solutions [7].
Metal matrix composites, reinforced with nano-particles, are very promising materials
with many interesting properties. The nano-particles, having typically physical and chemical properties drastically different than the matrix, improve it in terms of mechanical strength, hardness, dimensional stability, ductility, wear resistance or fracture toughness at room and elevated temperatures. There are examples that MMnCs based on lightweight metals, such as Al and Mg, achieve high strength, hardness and wear resistance along with low weight [8-11]. Exploring HEAs as a matrix for a generation of composites constitutes a novel approach with potentially great engineering implications. For example, HEA used as a binder in WC with Al0.5CoCrCuFeNi [12] and in Ti(C,N)-based cermets of AlCoCrFeNi [13] caused significant improvements in mechanical properties [14]. Fan et al. [15] produced in-situ composite based on (FeCrNiCo)Al0.75Cu0.25 with 10 vol.% TiC using the self-propagating high-temperature synthesis. The composite microstructure consisted of the FCC+BCC matrix with TiC particles having a size of up to 7 µm.
The most common method of manufacturing nano-composites based on high melting
temperature alloys and ex-situ introduced reinforcement is powder metallurgy, known for generating nano-crystalline grain size [16]. The fine grain size along with the presence of reinforcement particles with size reduced to the nanometer scale (< 100 nm) largely contribute to the improved strength of materials via the Hall–Petch relationship and grain boundary strengthening. There is ongoing discussion whether other mechanisms, such as Orowan looping, the coefficient of thermal expansion and mismatch strengthening, may also play an important role in MMnCs performance [17-19]. Since the single FCC structure of the CoCrFeMnNi HEA has rather low strength accompanied by high plasticity [20-22], it is important to improve alloy
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
3
strengthening. So far, there was no successful attempt to refine the microstructure of these alloys by cold work and recrystallization [23], severe plastic deformation [24] or cryogenic treatments [25].
In this paper, novel composites, consisting of CoCrFeMnNi HEA matrix, created by
combining five elements in equal atomic concentrations and ex-situ inserted SiC nano-particles, were designed and synthesized by powder metallurgy routes. The aim was to determine the influence of SiC nano-particles on microstructure and mechanical properties of the new HEA type matrix and to identify their strengthening mechanisms.
2. Experimental

sections.heading: 2.1 Composite manufacturing
sections.text: As the first step of alloy manufacturing, Co, Cr, Fe, Mn and Ni equi-atomic element blends of 99.5%) purity were mechanically alloyed in a Fritsch planetary type ball mill, Pulverisette-P5, for 35 h at 200 rpm at a ball to powder weight ratio of 10:1, using stainless steel vials and balls. N-heptane was introduced as the process controlling agent (PCA) to avoid cold welding and to prevent metal oxidation. The mechanical alloying process was monitored by regular powder extraction at intervals of 5, 10, 20 and 35 h. Then, the as-milled CoCrFeMnNi powder was mixed with SiC nanoparticles in the amount of 5 wt.% in a planetary ball mill at 100 rpm for 5 h, referred to later as mixing with low energy, and at 200 rpm for 5 h, referred to as mixing with high energy. Spherical β-SiC nano-particles with a size of 20-50 nm supplied by Alpha Aesar were used in the study (Fig. 1). The prepared powders were consolidated using Hot Isostatic Pressing (HIP, AIP30-10H) at 1000˚C for 15 min under 150-bar isostatic pressure in an argon atmosphere.

sections.heading: 2.2 Microstructure and property examinations
sections.text:
Samples used for optical and scanning electron microscopy were polished and etched with 5% Nital. The quantitative metallographic analysis was performed using a Leica QUIN image analysis system. X-ray measurements of the phase composition were performed using a Philips PW1740 diffractometer and CoKα filtered radiation. The microstructure was examined using an
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
4
FEI SEM XL30 (FEI Company, Hillsboro, OR) scanning electron microscope equipped with an EDAX GEMINI 4000 energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer. Microstructure and selected area electron diffraction (SAD) studies were also performed using Tecnai G2 F20 transmission electron microscopes (TEM). Micro-chemical analysis was conducted using TEM equipment in both transmission and scanning transmission (STEM) modes coupled with Integrated EnergyDispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). The samples for TEM were thinned using a Struers Tenupol-5 jet polisher, Struers, Inc., Cleveland, OH, in an electrolyte consisting of 20 vol.% HClO4 and 80 vol.% CH3OH at sub-zero temperatures. The Vickers hardness was measured under a load of 5 kg for 15 s using a Zwick/ZHU 250 tester and a CSM Instruments microhardness tester under a load of 100 g, following the ASTM E9 standard. An average of five readings on each sample was used. Young's modulus was determined from micro-indentation tests [26]. The compression test was performed at room temperature on cylindrical samples with 4 mm in diameter and 6 mm in height, following the PN-57/H-04320 standard.
3. Results

sections.heading: 3.1 Microstructure of the CoCrFeMnNi base
sections.text:
The general microstructure of the as-HIP-ed CoCrFeMnNi HEA is shown in Fig. 2a. It consists of irregular grains with a size of up to 28 µm, exhibiting a gray contrast among which are located lightly etched areas with a content of 12 vol. %. The SEM-BSE examinations of the base alloy revealed a dual phase structure consisting of a light matrix and a second phase with a contribution of 14 vol. % and having a dark contrast (Fig. 2b). The EDS analysis from the light area (location 1, Fig. 2b, Tab. 1) showed a near equiatomic concentration of all elements excluding Cr. The content of the latter reached 12 at. %. The analysis of the area with a distinct gray contrast marked as location 2 in Fig. 2b confirmed a significant increase in the content of Cr up to 32 at. % (details in Tab. 1). This suggests the simultaneous presence of two solid solutions with different Cr concentrations or an additional phase with high Cr concentration. In order to precisely determine the phase composition, TEM examinations under high magnifications have been conducted.
High magnification observations using TEM revealed details of microstructure and phase
composition of the CoCrFeMnNi base HEA. Fig. 3 shows a bright field image with an SAD pattern, taken from the light contrast area in Fig. 2b. The diffraction confirmed the existence of
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
5
solid solution with FCC structure and the following phase composition: 20.5 at.% Cr, 16.1 at. % Mn, 19.8 at.% Fe, 21.5 at.% Co and 22.1 at.% Ni. The TEM image of another region shows equiaxed grains with the size of 20-230 nm and various contrasts, indicating the differences in crystallographic orientation and/or chemical composition (Fig. 4a). The SAD pattern from the grain marked with a solid ring in Fig. 4a shows (11-1) and (200) reflections of the solid solution with the FCC structure and corresponding to the [011] zone axis (Fig. 4b). In this region, SAD patterns revealed the σ-phase [001] with an orthorhombic lattice as well as the M23C6 carbides (where M= Cr, Fe, Co) with a cubic structure generating strong reflections from (1-1-1), (111) and [01-1] zone axis, respectively (Figs. 4c and 4d).
X-ray bulk analysis detected occurrence of predominant content of solid solution with
FCC structure and a small amount of M23C6 carbides (Fig. 5a). It is believed that the latter formed due to the presence of C originating from the heptan medium as well as from steel balls used during the mechanical synthesis. This side effect is difficult to avoid when the blend includes Cr, which is highly prone to react with C. A similar phenomenon was observed in Ref. [27-29], e.g. Pickering et al. [27] experienced in the arc cast CoCrFeMnNi HEA formation of M23C6 after long periods of annealing at 700˚C due to negligible contamination by carbon.
The TEM-EDS quantitative chemical analysis from the grains where SADs were taken,
marked as the square areas of 1 to 4 in Fig. 4a, are presented in Tab. 2. The lattice parameters calculated using the EDS analysis based on concentrations of elements in solid solutions reached a = 0.363 nm and a = 0.369 nm for locations 1 and 3 in Fig. 4a, respectively. It is suspected that differences are associated with variations in concentrations of Cr. The constants are consistent with the values obtained by X-ray measurements, which derived the average lattice parameter of 0.359 nm. Nevertheless, due to the varying content of Cr between individual grains, two FCC solid solution structures were identified which is similar to literature observations. For example, Ji et al. [22] reported a co-existence of two FCC structures with a slight deviation in lattice constants in the CoCrFeMnNi HEA spark plasma sintered alloy, while a single phase was observed after direct casting in the arc melted CoCrFeMnNi HEA [24, 25]. It looks that the alloy synthesis technique affects the Cr segregation. Different manufacturing methods result in differences in phase compositions of HEAs, which is associated with essentially different phase formation mechanisms, leading to nano-crystalline
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
6
and metastable structures being obtained through powder metallurgy [16]. As determined in our laboratory practice, segregation of Cr enriched particles occurs at the earlier stage of powder mechanical synthesis. The phases formed during sintering in this study were affected by the level of Cr concentration: carbides for high Cr content and σ-phase for low Cr content. The results indicate that Cr affects phase formation in the studied alloy what is directly related to the phase structure, diffusion coefficient and an interaction with other elements. Hence, at high Cr concentration, carbides and sigma phase were formed while for low Cr concentration solid solution was present.
During sintering in this study, carbides, for high Cr content, or σ-phase for lower Cr
content, were formed depending on the level of Cr concentration. Another side effect of alloy synthesis was formation of metallic oxides. Namely, during TEM investigations of sintered base alloys, some oxides of Mn and Cr were identified. Due to high affinity of Cr and Mn to oxygen, it is extremely difficult to avoid their formation during mechanical alloying. According to the literature, such oxide particles have often been observed also in the arc-melted CrMnFeCoNi HEA [23, 26, 30-33].
3.2 Microstructure of SiC - CoCrFeMnNi nano-composites
In the planetary ball mill the milling media have generally an increased energy because milling stock and balls come off the inner wall of the vial at the centrifugal forces many times exceeding the gravitational acceleration. However, the milling energy can be diversified by controlling the rotation speed. For the purpose of composite synthesis in this study, two rotation speeds of 100 rpm and 200 rpm, corresponding to low and high energy, were used.

sections.heading: 3.2.1 SiC blends mixed with low energy
sections.text:
Additions of SiC nano-particles to the HEA base led to significant changes in the alloy microstructure. Sintered samples from blends mixed at low energy with 100 rpm using a planetary ball mill revealed a presence of equiaxed grains with an average size of 15 µm surrounded by smaller ones generally below 5 µm (Fig. 6a). The SEM-BSE analysis showed a dual phase structure consisting of a light matrix (EDS location 3 in Fig. 6b, Tab. 1) and phase having a gray contrast. The amount of the latter phase reached 12 vol.% (EDS location 4 in Fig. 6b, Tab. 1). Its distribution was not homogeneous; it was found that the front of the
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
7
transformation led to the refinement of the gray contrast phase inside some grains, marked with a dotted line in Fig. 6b. This may have been caused by the presence of a non-equilibrium composition of powders after mechanical synthesis, which exhibited tendency towards redistribution and homogenization during sintering. The EDS analysis also revealed a small concentration of Si within grains and along grain boundaries, suggesting the occurrence of SiC nano-particles. In contrast to the base HEA alloy without SiC particles, all regions with gray contrast representing FCC solid solution, were occupied by the reinforcement particles. Dark contrast regions in the microstructure correspond to sites with the agglomeration of SiC powders (Fig. 6b). The X-ray analysis, shown previously as pattern b in Fig. 5, confirmed the presence of FCC solid solution with low-intensity peaks coming from the M23C6 carbides and from β-SiC with the cubic structure.
The TEM bright field microstructure of the CoCrFeMnNi HEA with the addition of 5
wt.% SiC is shown in Fig. 7. The SiC nano-particles having a size of 15-55 nm are distributed along grain boundaries of the FCC solid solution. Additionally, changes in contrast in the area around the particles suggest the presence of defects as well as strains, marked with arrows. The bright field image in Fig. 8a shows fine equiaxed grains with the FCC structure (SAD in Fig. 8b) and other Cr-enriched grains, in which two kinds of carbides coexist: M23C6, with a cubic structure, and M7C3 (where M=Cr, Fe, Co), with a hexagonal lattice (SAD in Fig. 8c). The coexistence of two kinds of carbides was caused by transformation of M23C6, into M7C3 during high temperature sintering. It is believed that the presence of high carbon carbides may be caused by the partial decomposition of SiC, which resulted in the enrichment in carbon of some particles containing high volumes of Cr. It is known that Cr has a high affinity to carbon and easily forms carbides [34]. For example, Z. Wang et al. [35] showed that additions of interstitial atoms such as carbon or boron to the CoCrFeMnNi HEA, within the range of their solubility, led to significant increase in mechanical properties due to solid solution hardening.
In order to determine the distribution of elements in the CoCrFeMnNi HEA with the
addition of 5 wt.% of SiC, a qualitative chemical analysis was conducted, using EDS with the TEM microscope operated in the STEM mode. The changes in contrast featured in Fig. 9a revealed differences in chemical composition of HEA grains. The chemical composition from areas 5 and 6 in Fig. 9a, measured by EDS, is listed in Table 2. Additionally, maps of individual elemental distributions (Fig. 9 b-g) in the area marked with the frame in Fig. 9a confirmed the
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
8
inhomogeneous distribution of chromium, portrayed in yellow in Fig. 9f. Also, phenomenon of chemical segregation within HEAs is often reported by other researchers for different types of solid solutions. Takeuchi [36] observed segregations of Tb and Gd to grain boundaries in high entropy hexagonal YGdTbDyLu and GdTbDyTmLu alloys. The segregation phenomenon is common for materials manufactured by powder metallurgy [16]. Additionally, EDS analysis of small spherical particles, location 7, Fig. 9a, showed the increased concentration of Si up to 11.2 at. %. Details of analysis are presented in Tab. 2, confirming the presence of SiC particles. Beyond SiC particles, the Si mapping revealed its near homogeneous distribution in the HEA matrix (Fig. 9g).
3.2.2 SiC blends mixed with high energy
In order to determine the influence of mixing conditions of the CoCrFeMnNi HEA with SiC, a blend containing 5 wt.% SiC was also prepared by high energy mixing through mechanical synthesis at 200 rpm for 5h. These experimental conditions during composite generation led to a partial reaction of the SiC nano-particles with the matrix at the time of sintering, as confirmed by X-ray diffraction (Fig. 10). In addition to the FCC solid solution, a high volume of BCC as well as M7C3, M23C7 carbides and σ-phase were revealed. It is likely that substantial refining of SiC powders and their incorporation into grains of the base alloy induced the reaction between SiC and the matrix. As a result, carbon formed complex carbides, while silicon formed the BCC structure. These experiments revealed that mixing of nano-SiC particles with HEA blends, under conditions of mechanical synthesis with high energy do not suit the composite manufacturing. Namely, the high energy synthesis leads to formation of complex phases making the material hard and brittle.

sections.heading: 3.4 Mechanical properties
sections.text:
3.4.1 CoCrFeMnNi base The microhardness of CoCrFeMnNi powders after 35 h of milling reached 688 HV and this high value, unusual for FCC structure material, was associated with the presence of strains and defects in the mechanically alloyed material [16]. After sintering, the average hardness of the HEA alloy decreased to 484 HV (Tab. 3). There was some microhardness anisotropy with grain interiors having 402 HV and grain boundary regions reaching 450 HV. Such low values were caused by
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
9
the FCC structure of the solid solution, which in comparison with the CoCrFeMnNi powder directly after milling revealed a released tension and coarsened microstructure.
The room temperature compression test was carried out to determine the deformation
behaviour of the CoCrFeMnNi HEA. The stress-strain plots in Fig. 11 shows substantial work hardening and ductility of the CoCrFeMnNi base HEA. The compression strength reaching 2660 MPa was accompanied by a high strain of 35.5%, while yield stress was 1180 MPa. Young's modulus, determined based on microhardness indentations, was 184 GPa. The mechanical properties of the studied alloys are also listed in Tab. 3 in order to facilitate their comparison. It has been proven that mechanical alloying and sintering lead to better mechanical properties than those obtained for the material in as-cast state, which also results from the Hall Petch strengthening [22, 37, 38] and from the non-single solid solution structure.

sections.heading: 3.4.2 CoCrFeMnNi - SiC nano-composites
sections.text:
The average hardness of the composite containing 5 wt.% SiC, mixed at low energy, reached 485 HV and was similar to the base CoCrFeMnNi HEA. This is due to the presence of the soft FCC matrix; although the microhardness measurements showed an increased value up to 460 HV in the area of the grain boundary, suggesting the segregation of SiC particles, while microhardness inside the grains was 428 HV. The compression curve of the composite containing 5 wt.% SiC, marked as a dotted line in Fig. 11, showed that yield stress increased to 1480 MPa, plastic strain reached 26.5 %, while the compression strength decreased to 2390 MPa.
The composite with the same 5 wt.% of SiC but mixed at high energy achieved a
significantly higher average hardness of 699 HV. It is believed that the increased hardness was caused by partial reaction of SiC particles with the matrix. The dash-dotted curve in Fig. 11 depicts compression characteristics of this composite. The highest yield stress of 1900 MPa along with the compressive strength of 2000 MPa and at 0.5% plasticity was achieved. Such a low ductility, most likely, is associated with the presence of high volume of complex carbides and BCC structures.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
10
4. Discussion
Metal matrix composites, reinforced with nano-particles, develop unique properties due to the fact that in addition to other strengthening effects the reduced size of the reinforcement phase to the nano-scale is such that interaction of particles with dislocations becomes of significant importance. For a given composite matrix, including as exotic as high entropy alloys, the key challenge is to select the strengthening phase and the literature provides a number of examples. For matrices of Al, Mg, Ti or Cu the reinforcement nano-particles include oxides, Al2O3, Y2O3, nitrides Si3N4, AlN, carbides TiC, SiC, borides TiB2, hydrates TiH2, different allotropes of carbon and carbon nanotubes [39]. Of all of them, the most commonly used are carborundum and alumina. Thus, during design of HEA composites in this study, after analysis of all reinforcement characteristics, SiC has been selected as well suited the HEA matrix.
There are also challenges at manufacturing stages to generate quality nano-composites
where reinforcement particles are effective in improving properties of the matrix. The first one is the wettability of the reinforcement phase by the molten metal. The other one is to create a uniform dispersion of the reinforcement phase within the matrix. As portrayed by microstructure imaging throughout the paper, employing manufacturing through mechanical alloying and hot isostatic pressing allowed us to achieve both goals. There is no clogging or agglomeration of particles and interface particle/matrix imaging under magnifications of TEM supports particle wettability by the matrix.
The composites synthesized in this study created novel high entropy alloys with highly
improved mechanical properties. In particular, additions of 5 wt.% of SiC nano-particles increased yield strength of the CoCrFeMnNi HEA from 1180 MPa to 1480 MPa. The values of Young's modulus, determined based on microhardness indentations for the sample containing 5 wt.% SiC mixed at low energy and mixed at high energy, were 229 and 214 GPa, respectively. The positive effect of SiC particles is attributed to the contribution of grain size [39] and blocked deformation of the FCC solid solution. The achieved strengthening is supported by literature observations. For example, Ji et al. [22] in the CoCrFeMnNi spark plasma sintered sample reported low compressive strength, which was 1987 MPa at 10 % plasticity, and the yield strength of about 1500 MPa. For comparison this result is plotted as triangle in Fig. 13. The reduction in mechanical properties, such as lower compressive strength or plasticity, may be
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
11
caused by the porosity of the spark plasma sintered sample. Additionally, relatively high yield strength, as reported in [22], suggests that, besides the FCC structure, the samples contained intermetallic compounds or a BCC solid solution. The above hypothesis can be confirmed by Wang et al. [37] where an atomized CoCrFeMnNi HEA with a single FCC structure obtained yield stress of 600 MPa and compressive strength around 1000 MPa after sintering. Again, for a comparison, this result is plotted as a square marker in Fig. 11. The yield stress of the as-cast CoCrFeMnNi HEA with a coarse FCC single solid solution was in the range of 400-600 MPa [20].
The improved mechanical properties of metal matrix nano-composites are the result of
contributions from several strengthening mechanism, including: load transfer effect, Hall-Petch strengthening, Orowan strengthening, coefficient of thermal expansion and elastic modulus mismatch as well as enhanced dislocation density [39]. The final strength of the composite, σc, can be evaluated by summing the above contributions related to the single strengthening effects, ∆σi, with the original yield strength of the unreinforced matrix, ∆σm, what is expressed as [39]:
= + ∑ (1)
In general, the strength of the alloy is determined by the size, distribution and the coherency of the precipitates in the matrix. Small and not-too-hard precipitates are generally sheared by the moving dislocations, described as the Friedel effect. In a situation of bigger and stronger particles the moving dislocations pass them by bowing. The particles strength increases with increasing their size until it can be shared by dislocations. At some point of size increase, the shearing becomes difficult and the simpler option for dislocations is to pass them via the Orowan mechanism. This results in a reduction in hardness with further increase in precipitate size. When the fraction of precipitates/particles shearing and bowing by the dislocations is equal, the alloys achieve peak strength. Mechanical properties of high entropy matrix nano-composites are directly related with applied reinforcement and its reaction with matrix. It is difficult to determine the individual effect of each phase, which strengthens the composite. Among the reinforcement phases the highest hardness of 3000 HV have SiC nano-particles [40], the σ-phase reaches hardness up to 1000 HV [41] while the M23C6/M7C3 carbides reach 1600 HV [42]. It is assumed that the addition of SiC nano-particles, homogeneously dispersed in the matrix, had the
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
12
key impact and led to the increase of properties in ex-situ composites obtained with the use of low energy mixing. Nevertheless, apart from properties of strengthening phases also its volume fraction and distribution as well as interactions with the matrix are important factors. The M23C6/M7C3 carbides, sigma as well as BCC solid solution are in-situ formed strengthening phases, which are uniformly distributed in the soft FCC. In the sample, mixed with high energy their concentration increased. As a result, it led to low plasticity, due to a presence of high number of hard particles which limit grain deformation. Additionally, load-bearing effect, which relies on the shear transfer of load from the soft matrix to the hard particles, is reinforcing mechanism due to a strong cohesion between the matrix and reinforcement. It should be assumed that nano-SiC particles will possess higher thermal stability than M23C6/M7C3 carbides and sigma. It can exert the positive influence on mechanical properties of the alloy at elevated temperatures.
TEM imaging of deformed samples provide important contribution into composite
deformation mechanism. Two key factors responsible for plasticity of composites are the movement of dislocations and twinning. At the early stage of deformation, especially at the matrix/reinforcement interface region, an increase in the dislocation density, which is also observed in [43, 44], was responsible for work-hardening during compression test. For the multielement alloy, the stacking fault energy is relatively low, what enhanced twin formation. The stacking fault energy of a dissociated dislocation is relatively high causing blockage of its movement in the most active slip systems. In places where an accumulation of dislocations took place, most often at grain boundary or area of particles, generation of twins took place. It should be noted that an addition of particles enhanced blocking the movement of dislocations, the same increasing probability of twin formation. On the other hand, it is believed that at the stage when twins start rising, the presence of nano-SiC particles may block their further growth. A microstructure of the compressed composite showed twins along with point defects seen as dark contrast features in the solid solution, SiC particles along grain boundaries and strongly deformed grains (Fig. 12a). According to SAD pattern in Fig. 12b, strong reflections in the FCC at zone axis orientation of [110] with twins on the {1–11} plane are present. This suggests that the main mechanism controlling the material plasticity is twinning of the FCC solid solution. Nevertheless, the sample obtained by high energy of mixing revealed limited plasticity with deformation below 0.5% due to the partial reaction of SiC particles with grains enriched in Cr,
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
13
which led to the formation of brittle carbides (Fig. 12c). Additionally, it looks that carbon partially dissolved in the FCC solid solution, leading to its hardening. Similar conclusions are reported in Ref. [22] where plasticity of the CoCrFeMnNi HEA at room temperature was associated with formation of twins. However, the decrease in temperature to that of liquid nitrogen brings about deformation caused by blocking movement of dislocations and twinning. This proves that particles do not change the mechanism of composite deformation beyond that valid for the matrix.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text:
The microstructure of the CoCrFeMnNi HEA, manufactured using mechanical alloying followed by hot isostatic pressing at 1000˚C for 15 min consisted of a face centered solid solution of all elemental ingredients with traces of M23C6 carbides and σ-phase. The latter phases came as the secondary effect of the manufacturing cycle.
The nonporous, compact CoCrFeMnNi HEA composites with the addition of 5 wt.% β-SiC nano-particles were synthesized through low energy mixing at 100 rpm for 5 h followed by hot isostatic pressing at 1000˚C for 15 min under 150 bar. The as-sintered microstructure of the composite consisted of SiC particles, FCC solid solution, M23C6/M7C3 carbides and σphase. The SiC particles with a size of 15-55 nm were distributed along grain boundaries of FCC matrix.
The application of a high energy mechanical alloying process to the mixing of CoCrFeMnNi base HEA with SiC nano-particles led to their a reaction with the matrix after sintering. As a result, hard phases were formed causing embrittlement of the composite.
The CoCrFeMnNi HEA subjected to room temperature compression exhibited a very strong hardening effect resulting in high compression strength of 2660 MPa and yield strength of 1180 MPa at a plasticity up to 35.5%. The addition of 5 wt.% of SiC nano-particles with a size of 20-50 nm substantially increased yield strength to 1480 MPA and 1940 MPa for
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
14
blending at 100 rpm and 200 rpm. For the same blending process of 100 rpm and 200 rpm, Young’s modulus increased from 184 MPa to 229 GPa and 214 GPa, respectively. A presence of high density twins within the FCC solid solution matrix accompanied by high dislocation density after composite deformation indicates that strengthening mechanism of nano-composites was the same as the metal matrix.

metadata.abstractText: Novel metal matrix nanocomposites were designed exploring the CoCrFeMnNi high entropy alloy as a matrix and SiC spherical nanoparticles with a diameter of 20-50 nm as a reinforcement phase, and manufactured by mechanical alloying followed by hot isostatic sintering. After reaction at 1000 ̊C for 15 min the microstructure consisted of a matrix with a face centered solid solution of all elemental ingredients with traces of M23C6/M7C3 carbides (where M= Cr, Fe, Co), σ-phase and SiC nano-particles distributed along grain boundaries of the matrix. Additions of 5 wt.% of SiC nano-particles increased the room temperature compressive yield strength of the CoCrFeMnNi base from 1180 MPa to 1480 MPa, accompanied by a decrease in compressive strength and plasticity. The results are discussed in terms of mechanisms controlling the strengthening process in nano-composites with high entropy alloy matrix.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
